issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual specification) requires messageOnMilk() to return a String (e.g. "[Animal Type] [name] is milked") and the template Main prints the return value of messageOnMilk(). However, the solution repository defines Milkable.messageOnMilk() to return boolean and the Seal/Goat implementations print the milk message internally and return true. This contradicts the specified return type and the expected usage (printing the returned String) and will confuse students and break expected output-based tests.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Milkable API and implementations consistent with the problem statement: change Milkable.messageOnMilk() to return String (signature: String messageOnMilk()). Update Goat and Seal to return the formatted String (e.g. return "Goat " + getName() + " is milked"; and return "Seal " + getName() + " is milked";) instead of printing and returning boolean. Remove internal printing from these methods and let callers (e.g. Main or test code / Farm) print the returned String. This aligns the solution with the UML and the template's usage.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify Milkable.messageOnMilk() as returning a String (the textual message "[Animal Type] [name] is milked") and examples in the description / Main expect to print that return value. In the solution repository the Milkable interface and its implementations use the same method name messageOnMilk(), but the return type is boolean and the implementations print the milk message to stdout and return true. Although the identifier (messageOnMilk) is consistent, the conceptual contract (a method that returns the milk-message String) differs across artifacts, forcing students to reconcile two different representations of the same conceptual operation and likely causing confusion when mapping the problem requirements to the provided/expected API.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Milkable API with the problem statement: declare Milkable.messageOnMilk() to return String, and update all implementations (Seal, Goat) to return the formatted string (e.g. "Goat Buttinsky is milked") instead of printing and returning boolean. Update any client code (e.g. Main) to print the returned String. This preserves the intended contract and removes the need for students to reconcile two different representations of the same concept.
